Let's start with the weeping angels, they're
almost as old as old as the universe, that's
13.8 billion years by the way.
And they have an ingenious defence mechanism.

When they're not being observed they move
quickly and silently.

But when they are being observed, they quantum
lock, turning themselves into stone.

And this is actually very similar to the quantum
zero effect, when a normally unstable particle,

when continuously observed, won't actually
decay.
Essentially, its normal evolution is frozen.

This actually taps into the weird things about
the microscopic world, that the act of observing
something actually changes its state.
But this is also a massive problem.
What counts as an observation?

If you go by the original so-called Copenhagen
interpretation, then it's all down to a human
being.

But then you get the absurdities such as Schrodinger's
Cat where you have something both as big and

normal as a cat being both dead and alive
at the same time.

Next up it's the cyber men.

Cybernetically augmented humanoids, that suppress
emotions and want to cyber-convert you into
their ranks.

Now the original cybermen suffered a massive
weakness to gold.

Some say that's because its non-corrosive
nature would block up their respiratory system
when inhaled.

But then again, things like gold coins, gold
tipped bullets, and even a golden ticket spelled

their downfall in some episodes, which makes
me think that there is an adverse chemical
reaction going on.

This is actually really surprising because
gold isn't very reactive at all.

In fact it's right at the bottom of the reactivity
series of metals.

This is because its unpaired electron that
it needs to get rid of in order to react is

actually at a lower energy level than some
of its paired electrons.

So whilst gold would like to get rid of that
unpaired electron it can't because it would

make those paired higher energy electrons
unstable.

So if the cybermen are reacting so badly to
gold it makes me think that some part of them

must compose of a super strong oxidising agent,
when then would readily react with anything

else, iron, aluminium, hydrogen gas, that's
a massive weakness in my books.

Of course a discussion of Doctor Who's monsters

are in fact real.

In fact US Navy's laser weapon system, works
against drones.

A laser produces highly focused light waves
which mean it's extremely accurate.

By bombarding a target with the photons of
light you can heat it up and can cause it

to oblate, catch fire, or just generally cause
damage.

The thing is though is that it takes a lot
of power, one reason being because of dust
in the atmosphere.

These will heat up before the light even gets

Then again this is a problem we have overcome

ray.

There's no beam of light, there's no x-ray

It turns out that these directed energy weapons

the likes of missiles so they're not only
